questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with hypertension, sweating, and frequent headaches. Imaging reveals a thyroid nodule, and tests show elevated serum calcitonin. The family history includes similar early-onset cases. What condition is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.explanation:
Syndrome

Key Features

Genetic Mutation

MEN 2A
  • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Primary Hyperparathyroidism

RET proto-oncogene gain of function

- elevated tyrosine kinase

MEN 2B
  • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC) (more aggressive)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Mucosal Neuromas
  • Marfanoid Habitus

RET proto-oncogene gain of function

- elevated tyrosine kinase

Familial Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (FMTC) (Option D)

Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC) only

RET proto-oncogene gain of function

Cowden Syndrome

(Option C)
  • Thyroid Carcinoma (often follicular)
  • Benign Tumors (e.g., skin lesions)
  • Increased risk of breast and endometrial cancers.

Tumor suppressor PTEN gene

Loss of function

Werner syndrome
  • Follicular/ Papillary/Anaplastic Thyroid Carcinoma
  • Premature aging

WRN gene loss of function

Gardner Syndrome
  • Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma
  • Multiple colorectal polyps
  • Osteomas and soft tissue tumours

APC gene loss of function

MEN 1(Option A)
  • Primary hyperparathyroidism
  • Endocrine tumors
    • Gastrinoma
    • Insulinoma / VIPoma
    • Pituitary adenoma
    • Carcinoid tumor

MEN 1 gene on Chr. 11

Altered menin expression

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents with a rapidly growing thyroid mass accompanied by severe pain and hoarseness of voice. Imaging shows the direct invasion of surrounding structures, including the trachea and oesophagus. The diagnosis of anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is confirmed. In managing this condition, which of the following is not typically included?
A 45-year-old female recently underwent total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid carcinoma. Which of the following is not part of her post-surgical management?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediately start high-dose thyroxine (T4) to prevent hypothyroidism.

options.label: B
options.text: Stop thyroxine (T4) for 6 weeks before a whole-body scan.

options.label: C
options.text: Administer recombinant TSH if stopping thyroxine (T4) is intolerable.

options.label: D
options.text: PET scan if thyroglobulin rises despite normal neck USG and chest X-ray.

questions.correct_answer: A. Immediately start high-dose thyroxine (T4) to prevent hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoes a total thyroidectomy for a large multinodular goitre. Postoperatively, the patient is monitored for complications. Which of the following is least likely to occur?
A 45-year-old woman with a thyroid pathology is being considered for the procedure shown in the image. Which of the following conditions is a contraindication for this procedure?
A 55-year-old patient is undergoing a thyroidectomy, and the surgical team uses a specialized retractor to improve exposure and facilitate the operation. Identify the retractor.
questions.explanation:
Deaver’s Retractor (Option A): A General-purpose retractor used in various abdominal and thoracic surgeries

Richardson Retractor (Option C): Commonly used in abdominal surgery for abdominal wall retraction.


 

Volkmann Retractor (Option D): Often used in orthopaedic surgery, particularly for retracting soft tissues, but not specifically designed for thyroid surgery.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with symptoms of hyperthyroidism, including weight loss, palpitations, and tremors. A large thyroid nodule is noted on examination, and laboratory tests reveal elevated thyroid hormones with suppressed thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels. An ultrasound shows multiple nodules in the thyroid gland. Which of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Antithyroid drugs followed by total thyroidectomy

options.label: D
options.text: Treat with lugol iodine followed by surgery

questions.correct_answer: A. Antithyroid drugs followed by total thyroidectomy
questions.explanation:
Toxic multinodular goitre

Also known as Plummer’s disease, characterized by multiple overactive thyroid nodules causing hyperthyroidism.

Epidemiology

More common in females and occurs often after 60 years of age

Second most common cause of hyperthyroidism

More prevalent in Iodine deficient region

Pathophysiology

  • Chronic iodine deficiency or thyroid dysfunction → reduced hormone production → increased hypothalamic TRH secretion → persistent TSH stimulation of the thyroid gland → hyperplasia of thyroid nodules

 

  • Multiple somatic mutations of TSH receptor occur in long-standing goiters (> 60% of cases) → autonomous functioning of nodules (toxic MNG) → hyperthyroidism

Clinical features

  • Painless goiter with multiple palpable nodules
  • Symptoms of thyrotoxicosis

Lab investigations

  • ↑ T3 and ↓ TSH
  • Neck USG - multiple nodules within the thyroid parenchyma
  • Increased radioiodine uptake by multiple hyperfunctioning (hot) nodules
    • Decreased uptake by the rest of the gland
    • Hypofunctioning or cold nodules may also be present in the multinodular gland.

Management
  • Antithyroid drugs followed by Total Thyroidectomy are preferred.
    • Antithyroid drugs (Carbimazole, Methimazole) are to make the patient euthyroid and stabilize the patient before surgery.
    • Total thyroidectomy is to remove the toxic nodules and resolve the underlying problem.
  • Radioactive Iodine Therapy: Add - “(Iodine-131)”
    • Alternative or adjunctive treatment to destroy overactive thyroid tissue, especially useful if surgery is not feasible or desired (Option B)
    • Given in high doses as uptake is less compared to graves. Hence, it is not preferred before surgery.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with a history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis presents with a rapidly growing thyroid mass, dysphagia, dyspnea, and hoarseness. Biopsy confirms diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Which of the following is most appropriate for treating this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: External beam radiotherapy combined with chemotherapy

questions.correct_answer: B. External beam radiotherapy combined with chemotherapy

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman has recently undergone surgery for papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC). Postoperative pathology reports indicate: Tumour Size: 3.8 cm Extrathyroidal Invasion: Present No lymph node involvement No distant metastases Complete surgical resection Which of the following scoring systems is specifically used to assess the prognosis in the postoperative setting?
questions.explanation:
AGES System

AMES System

MACIS
  • Age
  • Histologic Grade
  • Extrathyroidal invasion
  • Size
  • Age
  • Metastasis
  • Extrathyroidal invasion
  • Size
  • Metastasis
  • Age
  • Completeness of original surgical resection
  • Extrathyroidal invasion
  • Size

Used for differentiated thyroid carcinomas to assess survival rates and identify high-risk patients.

A prognostic index which categorizes patients of differentiated thyroid carcinoma into Low and High risk

Used to evaluate the risk of recurrence and survival after initial treatment.

Factors

Good prognosis

Bad Prognosis

Size

< 1 cm

> 4 cm

Extrathyroidal invasion

Absent

Present

Age

< 40 years

> 40 years

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with midline neck swelling, persistent diarrhoea, and elevated serum calcitonin. Imaging shows the tumour confined to the thyroid without lymph node involvement. Histopathology reveals amyloid stroma. Which of the following is most appropriate for managing this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Total thyroidectomy with modified radical neck dissection

options.label: D
options.text: Total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection

questions.correct_answer: D. Total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection

questions.text: A 45-year-old with midline neck swelling and persistent diarrhoea has an enlarged thyroid gland. The family history includes pheochromocytoma and hyperparathyroidism. The image shows a histopathological examination of the thyroid. Which marker is most valuable for monitoring this condition?

A 48-year-old female presents with a midline neck swelling which moves upwards when she swallows. On examination, the swelling is suspected to be related to the thyroid gland. What is the most likely anatomical structure responsible for this movement, and what is the clinical significance of this feature?

options.label: A
options.text: Prevertebral fascia - distinguishing thyroid masses from parathyroid masses.

options.label: B
options.text: Pretracheal fascia - causes thyroid masses to move with swallowing.

options.label: C
options.text: Investing layer of the deep cervical fascia - encloses both the thyroid and trachea.

options.label: D
options.text: Superficial fascia - supports the thyroid gland’s position in the neck.

questions.correct_answer: B. Pretracheal fascia - causes thyroid masses to move with swallowing.

questions.text: A 32 year old female patient presented with complaints of midline swelling in neck without any palpable lymph nodes. FNAC and biopsy revealed the image below. Which of the following should be the management of this condition ?

options.label: A
options.text: Thyroidectomy + Removal of enlarged lymph nodes

options.label: B
options.text: Thyroidectomy + Removal of enlarged lymph nodes + MRND

questions.text: Which type of incision is typically used for thyroidectomy?

A 56-year-old female patient with a history of long-standing goiter, presented with complaints of sudden, painless increase in the size of swelling of the neck. Biopsy revealed the presence of follicles suggestive of carcinoma. What is the most common site and route of metastasis in this condition?

A 34-year-old female presents with neck swelling and a history of childhood neck irradiation for Hodgkin’s lymphoma. On examination, a hard mass is found in the neck. FNAC confirms thyroid carcinoma with HPE image given below, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Papillary

Follicular

(Option A)

Medullary

(Option B)

Anaplastic

(Option C)

Origin

Follicular cells

Follicular cells

Para follicular cells

Follicular cells

Risk factors
  • Radiation
  • Thyroglossal cyst
  • Hashimoto’s thyroiditis
  • Iodine deficiency
  • Multinodular goitre

-

-

Genetics

BRAF, RET-PTC

PAX-8,/PPAR-1, PTEN, P-53, RAS

RET, MEN II

P53

Clinical Manifestations
  • Seen in the 3rd to 4th decade.
  • Midline swelling in the anterior part of the neck
  • Occasionally, lateral aberrant thyroid is seen.
  • Seen in the 5th to 6th decade.
  • A sudden increase in the size of the swelling
  • Minimal or no pain
  • Raised calcitonin.
  • History of diarrhoea
  • Family history of pheochromocytoma or hyperparathyroidism
  

Metastasis

Lymphatic

Hematogenous

Both

Both and Direct invasion.

Histopathology
  • Optically clear nuclei (Orphan Annie eye nuclei)
  • Dystrophic calcification (Psammoma bodies)

Follicles (multiple foci are seen)

Amyloid deposition






 

Highly pleomorphic cells, spindle cells, giant cells, often areas of necrosis and mitotic figures.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman has a 5 cm thyroid tumour with extrathyroidal extension, cervical lymphadenopathy, and no distant metastasis. Based on the TNM staging system, what is the most accurate classification for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Category

Description

T (Primary Tumor)

T1

Tumor ≤ 2 cm, limited to the thyroid.

Tumor ≤ 1 cm, limited to the thyroid.

Tumor > 1 cm but ≤ 2 cm, limited to the thyroid.

T2

Tumor > 2 cm but ≤ 4 cm, limited to the thyroid.

T3

Tumor > 4 cm, limited to the thyroid or minimal extrathyroidal extension.
 

Tumor > 4 cm, limited to the thyroid.

Tumor with minimal extrathyroidal extension (e.g., strap muscles).

T4

Tumor of any size with extensive extrathyroidal extension.

T4a

Tumor invades subcutaneous soft tissues, larynx, trachea, oesophagus, or recurrent laryngeal nerve.

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral fascia or encases carotid artery or mediastinal vessels.

N (Regional Lymph Nodes)

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis.

N1

Regional lymph node metastasis.

N1a

Metastasis to level VI or VII lymph nodes (pre-tracheal, paratracheal, and prelaryngeal).

N1b

Metastasis to unilateral, bilateral, or contralateral cervical or superior mediastinal lymph nodes.

M (Distant Metastasis)

M0

No distant metastasis.

M1

Distant metastasis present.

questions.text: All the following forms the boundaries of Beahrs' triangle except?

A 60-year-old male undergoes a total thyroidectomy for a large multinodular goitre. Postoperatively, he experiences hoarseness and difficulty speaking. Which anatomical site is most commonly associated with this nerve injury during thyroidectomy?
During thyroid surgery on a patient, significant bleeding occurs near the superior pole of the thyroid gland. Which vessel branches from the artery supplying this region?
questions.explanation:
Artery

Origin

Supply

Superior Thyroid Artery

External carotid artery

The superior pole of the thyroid gland, thyroid isthmus, larynx, and surrounding tissues

Inferior Thyroid Artery

Thyrocervical trunk (branch of the subclavian artery)

Inferior pole of the thyroid gland

Thyroidea Ima Artery

Variable (may arise from the brachiocephalic trunk, common carotid artery, or aortic arch)

Provides additional blood supply to the thyroid gland.
